column1: https://www.ktnv.com/news/coronavirus/gov-si…"We’re calling it Nevada United Road Map to Recovery. We’re going to ease some of the restrictions that we had previously as it relates to retail curbside pickup. Some of our outdoor activities we’re going to loosen up what some of the restrictions are. Unfortunately we’re going to have to extend the stay at home order a little bit. We just have not reached exactly where we want to get in the downward trajectory. Our statistics have plateaued. We’ve got almost 5,000 cases now in the state of Nevada and 225 fatalities so those numbers have kind of stabilized and hospitalizations and intensive care hospitalizations have begun to decline. And so we are looking forward to continue to bring our economy back to life a little bit."

The goalposts always seem to be moving. At first, it was flatten the curve so we don't break the healthcare system. Now, it's lowering the number of new cases each day, despite ramping up testing, which will inevitably increase the number of diagnosed cases.
Well it looks i might as well change my trip to summer2021.

From across the pond it seems that those with the power are taking a cautious approach to ending the lockdowns - whether that's right or wrong is a matter for a different debate.I am no expert on the USA legal system but is a risk of some future legal proceedings because of deaths after the Gov makes a decision a factor in all of this.Just asking out of curiosity.

If you want a sneak preview of what "Nevada United Road Map To Recovery" looks like, probably look at Gavin Newsom's plan that he unveiled yesterday. I would expect similar "phases".Edited: 3:16 pm, April 29, 2020
Meanwhile, actual good news. https:/…

>>Meanwhile, actual good news. https:/…<<I have a few friends at Gilead, they woke up to their compnay stock being worth a little big more this morning. I sold all of my Gilead a while ago so wasnt able to capitalize (at least with Gilead stock) on todays positive news, although the market has responded positively to it as well.

Too bad you sold. I was debating purchasing shares a few weeks back, didn't pull the trigger unfortunately. Regardless, I'd take an open economy and healthy people over a little profit.Those friends know of any open positions for Lab Managers/Directors or in my case, PR, marketing, sales?
There might not be much of a Las Vegas by then.

https://news3lv.com/news/local/gov-sisolak-u…"Gov. Sisolak said casinos will reopen in the third or fourth phase of the recovery plan due to the heavy volume of people typically inside."So...it's gonna be months. I think PnS has the right idea with Harrah's Ak-chin or Biloxi.
To complement his news briefings, he could produce some charts or data tables to substantiate his decisions. It would give people some confidence and trust in what he is doing.

>>To complement his news briefings, he could produce some charts or data tables to substantiate his decisions. It would give people some confidence and trust in what he is doing.<<WHat makes you think that he wont when he unveils his plan tomorrow, Id assume that he will? Linked above was just an interview that he agreed to do.
Don't think there is going to be anything "United" about this plan except from the other states Nevada has locked-in-arms with.

>>WHat makes you think that he wont when he unveils his plan tomorrow, Id assume that he will? Linked above was just an interview that he agreed to do.<<He hasn't done it so far from what I've seen. When he mentions flattening the curve, I haven't seen him produce a diagram showing that, and what the specific decision points will be.

The Governor has continually provided slides and presented experts to talk during his briefings. I assume tomorrow will be no different. The big negative to his briefings are the technical issues when questions are asked and the sound that is happening on air. It literally sounds at times like the teacher Charlie Brown had on his cartoons..wah, wah, wah. The question portion is horrible as well. In spite of their best efforts it is full on amateur hour to the viewers.

TomC97: problem is most of our elected “leaders” are career politicians. They achieved some level of success by NOT making decisions and the various other behaviours of career politicians. In order to do this for this crisis most of them have completely ceded authority to appointed “health experts”. On and on....In Canada we have have a few provinces which almost no Covid hospitalizations remaining and very few deaths. A couple of them are moving forward in face of considerable opposition. Hopefully their success in reopening will pave the way for the rest of us.

“ He hasn't done it so far from what I've seen. When he mentions flattening the curve, I haven't seen him produce a diagram showing that, and what the specific decision points will be.”@Rallen, I have been watching them all. He really is presenting charts and graphs when talking to the State. He does not necessarily link them to anything specific to the future though. I do not care for him at all but I will give him that much.
The casinos might open but then when a guest or two gets and spreads the virus, the casino will close right back up.

“ The casinos might open but then when a guest or two gets and spreads the virus, the casino will close right back up.”Gosh, you could say that about everything I suppose. I wonder if non essential businesses around the US will simply close when a case is identified on premise. Do you think it will go like that?

I think so eventually. That’s what happened with the Spanish Flu Pandemic. It hung around for two years because businesses stayed open and the virus just plundered along killing.Edited: 6:58 pm, April 29, 2020
If anyone is still holding out hope Vegas will be open before the 4th of July... I am sorry.
Sisolak sure does love the control here it seems.

-:- Message from Tripadvisor staff -:-Tripadvisor staff removed this post because it did not meet Tripadvisor's forum guideline limiting each user to a single forums screen name.To review the Tripadvisor Forums Posting Guidelines, please follow this link: http://www.tripadvisor.com/pages/forums_posting_guidelines.htmlWe remove posts that do not follow our posting guidelines, and we reserve the right to remove any post for any reason.Removed on: 9:14 pm, April 29, 2020

I (did) travel to Vegas several times a year, and am hoping to go a couple of times this summer. Boy, your governor is an idiot. He will for sure copy the plan California has, since it doesn't seem like he has a brain cell of his own. What the hell is he waiting for?

@ChicagoThe wife of the Illinois governor isn't in Illinois anymore. She is hiding out at their estate in Florida. Took their private jet. The Mayor of Chicago is, I assume still getting her hair cut. I still don't see any politician wear a mask when speaking.Great examples of good enough for thee, not for me. Meanwhile the Governor of South Dakota, who never shut down the state mind you, is allowing businesses to choose how and when they open. A vacation to Deadwood looks more and more likely.
Ever been to Deadwood PnS? It’s a six hour drive for us roughly, but it’s definitely unique and different. You’d be a big fish in a small pond gambling wise.

No KC, I haven't. However, I want to keep my options open. I don't care about being the big fish at this point, though that sounds cool, I just want to have fun with some decent human beings in near proximity. I'm still crossing my fingers for Vegas, even if it means a fall or winter trip, but I want a backup plan. Really want to gamble and enjoy a pool. I will say, the old west vibe is cool, and if my wife is by my side anyplace can be fun.

I’m not sure about pools in Deadwood. We stayed at the Holiday Inn express, and I can’t remember if it had an indoor pool. Of course they have the old classic hotels like Bullock and Franklin. The Bullock is supposedly haunted. We went on a haunted tour there.

It won't be a fun pool but beggars can't be choosers. I would not stay anywhere where they claim it is haunted. Another option would be Morongo. It's close, one of the bartenders at Cielo is our buddy and always takes care of us. The casita villas have their own pool and a indoor/outdoor shower. We are also their middle out of three tiers there so there is that. Just going stir crazy here.
I get it, we were supposed go to Vegas in month, and had another weekend getaway prior to that. Now who knows what’ll happen.
Vegas runs on no rules...implementing many of rules will make Vegas into a place that nobody knows or will enjoy in the short to medium term

Just from Wisconsin, it't amazing how many areas with no new cases, yet the statewide orders are still in place. Where I live there were 3 total cases and no new cases for 14 days, yet we're still in shelter in place.

I think he's making the correct adjustment at this time. He is increasing the level of people movement by allowing non-essential retail to open up, albeit with the curbside delivery restriction.After two weeks of this activity, he will have the data on new COVID-19 cases. He can then assess if further activity can be opened up if there is no increase in cases, or a decrease in the number of cases may still continue. Worst case is if there is a significant rise in COVID-19 cases from this adjustment, then it is a lesser task to close back down than if there was a more widespread opening of businesses.
“I would not stay anywhere where they claim it is haunted.”Pns you scared of ghosts?
I ain’t afraid of no ghost. 13Edited: 9:55 am, April 30, 2020

I just don't like places with a weird vibe. Don't want to be on edge everytime there is a noise or something, especially when I am trying to sleep. Now, I'll visit a place that might be haunted. For example the Queen Mary in Long Beach. I will say parts of it were very creepy, especially the engine room. Just won't spend the night. Part of the reason why I won't stay at Bally's.

When I was 10 years old I started a short story with the words of a boy my age saying, "There ain't no such thing as ghosts."In other words, I knew this when I was a ten-year-old. And yes I've even "braved" the Queen Mary.

""Meanwhile the Governor of South Dakota, who never shut down the state mind you, is allowing businesses to choose how and when they open.A vacation to Deadwood looks more and more likely.""I woudn't mind taking a trip to Deadwood...was supposed to go a couple of years ago and it got called off....was going to meeting a couple of old college buddies there , and do some motorcycle rides. May have to bring up those old plans. And on a side note the South Dakota governor is kind of hot....

@JupiterThe SD Governor is hot, does not look late 40's. Regardless of policies, a pretty face, be it a man or woman helps to win races. I was looking at a map and apparently it is close to Sturgis and Mt. Rushmore so could do a few things on a trip vs just gamble. Like I said, Vegas is the target but it is always good to have a plan B and C.
PnS.... yea it's only about 20 minutes from Sturgis. And a lot of outdoor activities in the area.....

The ski resort town hotel I stay at is apparently haunted but I’ve never heard anything. I had to google that Bally’s thing. Wow.

I had a night in Deadwood on a 2018 summer road trip. Kitschy little place. Worth a night. It was also about 10 days before the bike rally in Sturgis. So it was neat to drive through there and see the preparations. Big encampments set up outside of town with fields and a few cabins for rent...and bars with big “ Sponsored by Budweiser “ signs being set up.

Aren't all South Dakota casinos shut down right now? even Deadwood..?Montana casinos ( there are no table games anywhere) are slated to be the first nationwide to reopen..week of May 4th ( yes, subject to change). Lots of good scenery in Montana, outdoorsy stuff..postcard -type views in areas...and cows ( twice as many cows as human residents)...Edited: 2:32 pm, April 30, 2020
They are still gambling on the machines in gas stations here in Wisconsin.

I've happily stayed at Luxor which many said is haunted. But the sheer number of horrific deaths at Bally's is a different story. Look up the Congress Plaza Hotel in Chicago. That is basically the Queen Mary if it was a building and not a boat. The casinos in South Dakota are closed, however I suspect they will open up relatively soon.Good to know about Montana.

Also check out the Alexandria in Downtown LA. My friend lived there. Someone died in his bathroom before he moved in. He showed me the basement and the elevator where a little girl was pushed down the shaft. Apparently the doors used to always open when he walked past on the 5th floor.
Deadwood's casinos are still properly closed.

This morning (Thu, Apr 30), at 11:30 a.m. local time, I went to the Governor's official website and there is NO Emergency Order posted extending the close-down orders beyond today. I know that Dictator Sisolak does not feel bound by petty restrictions such as the Constitution and does not feel that he needs legislative approval, but he must publish ("promulgate" is the legal term) his fiat decrees not by a press release and press conference but by legal means. …nv.gov/News/…I am really annoyed by this jerk (my true feelings would not pass the site's filters!) and his usurpation of power.
"I know that Dictator Sisolak..."Snicker.
Nevada Gov. Sisolak will share more guidance on Nevada's "Roadmap to Recovery" in a 5 p.m. address Thursday afternoon.https://www.fox5vegas.com/coronavirus/gov-si…

@2saltydawgs..I'm not familiar with the specific casino offerings in MT. but, as you say, looking at their offerings online, most slots appear to just be puffed - up Class 3 bingo games. Guess it might only appeal to the truly desperate :).Did you go in / near the Bozeman area at all? I went to school there many years ago..back during a time when women still went to the bathroom together (way back). It's an appealing area..lots of good trout fishing within an hour's drive.

Thank you. The Parlor, Presidential and Loft Suites at the Golden Nugget Lake Charles look amazing. I like the hot tub on the balcony of the Loft Suite. It will definitely be on the list.
We need another interview with they Mayor. I feel we could all use that content right now.

Absolutely Haymaker, I would enjoy that. The GN looks really awesome. Pool has a lazy river, there is another casino next door too for variety. Anything right now is a possibility. I just want some IRL human to human interaction, even if that means someone telling me how wrong I am over and over and over. Just include liquor, and all will be good with the world. LOL Another plus is Houston is where one of my wife's best friends lives. Her friend who was literally in the same tiny town as us last Christmas yet wouldn't leave her family's side for 10 minutes to see her. We could corner her haha.

In other news, Gov. Steve Sisolak was shocked when told Nevada actually has 16 counties, not one."I guess I'll have to visit White Pine and Lincoln one of the days", he said and then continued, mumbling under his breath, "wherever the hill they are."

Compare today's situation with the Hong Kong flu of 68-69, US population 200 million (320 million today) 100,000 deaths, mostly elderly, like today., Covid expected in 65,000 range, nothing closed down in 1969 and it was considered a "mild pandemic".
ranger. I am confused. Did they have shelter in place during Hong Flu of 68-69? And what number of deaths would be required to have shelter in place? Just curious.
“ Covid expected in 65,000 range”That’s about where things are now.So, no more deaths?Yay!

“population 200 million (320 million today) 100,000 deaths” That would equate to 160,000 deaths by percentage with our current US population. Assuming no quarantine this time Covid deaths would be much higher than the current 65,000. They might be near/above the 160,000 in the Hong Kong Flu model. Interesting.

I lived through the Hong Kong Flu as a kid. 4th grade. Lots of teachers and classmates got sick but no one died. Same for my family. My school (a small Catholic one) closed for a week but we just had to make it up during what would have been Easter break.I remember seeing a Hong Kong Flu coloring book (yes, really!). One page said, "This is your doctor's telephone. Color it busy."
@Kitty, Interesting, thanks for sharing

My neighbour is a principle and has basically given up. He’s got teachers at home that are pre recording lesson plans when they have time as they can’t send there own kids anywhere and so kids have questions and don’t get answers for a day and it just delays everything.

Hmmm...has anyone taken a look at the newest information coming from the CDC?What has been reported as 60,000+ deaths in the United States has now been changed to 37,000. 134 COVID19 deaths in Nevada. (and interestingly, zero here in NC?) (From the week ending 2/1/2020 until 4/25/2020)https:/…index.htm"Among 2,028 hospitalized adults with information on underlying medical conditions, 90.6% had at least one reported underlying medical condition, the most commonly reported were hypertension, obesity, chronic metabolic disease, and cardiovascular disease.""The overall cumulative COVID-19 associated hospitalization rate is 40.4 per 100,000, with the highest rates in people 65 years and older (131.6 per 100,000) and 50-64 years (63.7 per 100,000).Hospitalization rates for COVID-19 in adults (18-64 years) are higher than hospitalization rates for influenza at comparable time points* during the past 5 influenza seasons.For people 65 years and older, current COVID-19 hospitalization rates are similar to those observed during comparable time points* during recent high severity influenza seasons.For children (0-17 years), COVID-19 hospitalization rates are much lower than influenza hospitalization rates during recent influenza seasons."https:/…

Can't explain the above data. I don't have any background in that. This one makes more sense to me: Scroll over the states and it will say number of cases and number of deaths. North Carolina is listed as having 10,509 cases and 378 deaths. Last updated May 1.https:/…cases-in-us.html
as my 10th grade math teacher, Mr McGuinnes taught us...figures never lie but liars often figure.

"What has been reported as 60,000+ deaths in the United States has now been changed to 37,000."And Lin-duh found it.I hope you didn't think that you've discovered a big error, or cover up, and that the the numbers have been inflated by 100%. You did add in the number of deaths of those with both Covid-19 and pneumonia didn't you? That alone brings it to 54,000. Plus you did see footnote, "*Data during this period are incomplete because of the lag in time between when the death occurred and when the death certificate is completed, submitted to NCHS and processed for reporting purposes. This delay can range from 1 week to 8 weeks or more, depending on the jurisdiction, age, and cause of death."
Oh, so you mean that report is pretty much of no useful value ? I would agree.Edited: 2:26 pm, May 02, 2020
"Oh, so you mean that report is pretty much of no useful value ?"Of course not, I would never say anything so silly.
No. The COVID & pneumonia deaths are included in the cumulative COVID deaths.So you find a report from the CDC to be useless?

The 37k COVID deaths includes ALL deaths with ICD-10 code U07.1. (Which is people who tested positive for coronavirus, even if they were asymptomatic). The pneumonia and coronavirus deaths listed are those with both the U07.1 code AND a pneumonia code.The CDC also posted this on Facebook."According to the latest CDC COVIDView report, increases in hospitalization rates for COVID-19, which are cumulative, have started to level off. The hospitalization rate is highest among adults 65 and older and similar to what has been seen during a comparable time period during a recent high severity flu season."https:/…

"So you find a report from the CDC to be useless?"No, that's how I found your conclusions to be. The CDC is not in any way claiming the only 35,000 people have died of the coronavirus. The number is 65,000+. Even Fox State News is going with that number. But somehow you think you've discovered that everyone's wrong.I appreciate your help with linking website addresses, but man oh man.Edited: 10:21 pm, May 04, 2020
The 66,000+ now all died from covid related issues and all tested positive. We all know if you have underlying health issues it makes any illness difficult to fight off.
For those who claim the flu killed X, they need to read article in Washington Post that’s says those numbers are Estimates...would give link, but need to subscribe

I'm not claiming anything. I'm sharing direct quotes from the CDC, along with sources.I didn't say the flu kills X amount, I quoted the CDC's comment about it."The hospitalization rate is highest among adults 65 and older and similar to what has been seen during a comparable time period during a recent high severity flu season."I would imagine the experts who work for the CDC are aware of how flu deaths are documented/tracked.

2salty - they simply don’t have the testing capacity, although the president claims “we have tremendous testing” Whatever that means.

>>>The 66,000+ now all died from covid related issues and all tested positive. <<<That isn't true actually. The CDC guidelines allow reporting Covid 19 as a cause of death if "it is suspected or likely (e.g., the circumstances are compelling within a reasonable degree of certainty)" "In these instances, certifiers should use their best clinical judgement in determining if a COVID–19 infection was likely."https:/…vsrg03-508.pdfSo no, no positive test is needed to call it a Covid 19 death, even if it was not the primary cause.That doesn't mean deaths aren't under reported, but neither does it mean they are accurately reported.
...just a coincidence

"I'm not claiming anything. I'm sharing direct quotes from the CDC, along with sources"No you're not, you're misunderstanding the data. I guess I'm going to have to put it like this: Every news source and every expert place the number at 60,000+. So do you think that someone who calls herself "Lin-duh" found out that the numbers are almost half of what everyone else is using? Do you really think that? Even the WH was using those numbers during the president's unhinged briefing where he mused about people injecting cleaning solutions. But Lin-duh sitting at home, itching to go out, discovered that everyone's got the numbers wrong. Really? Obviously there's no point in replying back to you, so have at it.
lin-duh I believer FLW has called you out....And he says there is "no point replying to you" in his reply to you....go figure that out

cush, I already tried twice. It was the only way I could think of to get it through. Lin-duh (and she changed it to that for some reason about six months ago) did not discover that the numbers are wrong. As I said you have to roll the Covid 19 plus the pneumonia column into the first column for example.Edited: 10:21 pm, May 04, 2020

As of 30 seconds ago, this is what I see on the CDC website.TOTAL CASES-1,092,815TOTAL DEATHS-64,283
yay 100Edited: 1:54 pm, May 03, 2020
If you can’t believe The Hulk, who are we to believe...
I am just shocked hulk can count to 100

#102,As Hulk is from Phoenix, 100 is not hard.Each resident has at least one centipede as a pet, and just for that reason.Where I grew up in Mississippi, we all went to school barefoot, so we could count to 20!Now, I still have no idea what use our pet scorpions, in AZ have??HuntEdited: 10:31 pm, May 04, 2020
Lol, You Arizonans are really smart, lol
#102, ouch! That was uncalled for. I have typed 100 many times on this thread...
Q-dog, it wasn't me, it was the CDC...Cool, that was an unintentional rhyme. :-)
“ #102, ouch! That was uncalled for. I have typed 100 many times on this thread..“Hulk, I have posted the same insult to you in the past but you never came back to read it. I got you good.....zing!!
